## 4 Bivariate Viz


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
```

:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Load data
elections <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")

# Check it out
head(elections)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 0
#Part a 43%
ggplot(elections, aes(x = winner_20)) +
  geom_bar()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Part b
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_histogram()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 1
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_16, y = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 2 
 ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
 geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
geom_point: na.rm = FALSE
stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE
position_identity 
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point(shape = 3)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16, colour = "blue")) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_text(aes(label = state_abbr))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 3
#Republican suppport in 2020 and in 2016 appear to have a strong positive relationship. It seems as if Texas tends to deviate from this trend. 
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 4
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#a)
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#b)
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 5
ggplot(elections, aes(y = median_rent, x = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#This seems to have a slight negative relationship
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = median_age, x = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#This seems to have a very small positve relationship
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 6
#This doesn't give a clear picture of how the voter support in 2020 is related to historical votership. You can't really see count very well.
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 7
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_violin()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-2.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Red states have a higher median than both blue and purple states for republican votership in 2020. Red states also have the most outliers between the three. 
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Exercise 8 
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20, fill = historical)) +
  geom_density()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](activity-04_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
